title: A Protocol for Evaluating Vital Signs and Maternal-Fetal Parameters Using High-Resolution Ultrasound in Pregnant Mice
procedures:
Step-By-Step Method Details
Step-By-Step Method Details
Body Temperature Measurement
Timing: 5 min
Body temperature, one of the vital signs measured in the clinical setting, allows for evaluation of the presence of fever (i.e., elevated body temperature) or hypothermia (i.e., low body temperature). Interestingly, mice do not develop fever when they have systemic infection/inflammation; in fact, their body temperature decreases during these conditions (Copeland et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). Therefore, by measuring the body temperature we can evaluate the response of mice to different stimuli, indirectly distinguishing between a local and a systemic inflammatory response. In line with this concept, we recently investigated the changes in body temperature among different mouse models of lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced preterm birth. We showed that the intra-amniotic injection of LPS induced preterm birth without changing the body temperature, resembling the sub-clinical nature of this condition in pregnant women. However, the intra-peritoneal administration of LPS induced preterm birth accompanied by maternal hypothermia, showing that these models resemble a systemic inflammatory response (Gomez-Lopez et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]). A summary video of the procedure is shown in Methods Video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
Transport the mouse to the Vevo® imaging station.
Place a small amount of Aquagel® lubricant gel on a piece of gauze in preparation for the body temperature measurement. The gel will be used once you are holding the mouse (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
        Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
      
Methods Video S1. Measurement of Maternal Body Temperature (Refer to Body Temperature Measurement, Steps 2–8)
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Temperature Measurement Procedure
(A) Application of Aquagel® lubricant gel to the gauze pad.
(B) Dipping the rectal probe in Aquagel® lubricant gel.
(C) Insertion of the rectal probe into the mouse’s anus.
See also Methods Video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
Take the mouse out of the cage and place it on the wire lid.

Hold the mouse by the base of its tail, exposing the anus.
If the mouse begins to defecate (a natural stress response), gently remove any adherent feces with tweezers if needed.
Take the rectal probe (thermometer) and dip the tip of the probe into the Aquagel® lubricant gel that was previously prepared (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Stimulate the anal sphincter with the tip of the rectal probe and insert the rectal probe into the anus while holding the mouse firmly to avoid movement (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Look at the physiological monitor and record the temperature once it has stabilized.
Take the probe out carefully to avoid any damage to the rectum or anus.
Place the mouse back in its cage.
Clean the rectal probe with disinfectant spray.
Critical: We recommend measuring maternal temperature as the first step of the evaluation of physiological parameters because the body temperature of the mouse changes while under anesthesia. Be very careful to insert the rectal probe into the anus instead of the vagina. If you notice that the mouse is nervous, you can cover it with a napkin to keep it calm and avoid the risk of injury of the mouse
Note: Aquagel® can be stored at room temperature.
Blood Pressure Measurement
Timing: 40 min

One of the greatest physiological changes during pregnancy occurs in the maternal cardiovascular system, resulting in reduced maternal blood pressure and an increased resting pulse (Robson et al., 1989[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib18]; Clark et al., 1989[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Mahendru et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13]) due to hormonal and anatomical changes (Wilson et al., 1980[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib25]; Chapman et al., 1998[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). On the other hand, around 2%–7% of pregnant women present with pre-eclampsia, a pregnancy complication characterized by hypertension and proteinuria that has deleterious effects on both the mother and the fetus (Redman and Sargent, 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]; Chaiworapongsa et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]). Moreover, during severe inflammatory processes in humans, such as sepsis, maternal blood pressure decreases, causing hypotension (Singer et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib20]). Therefore, measuring blood pressure in pregnant mice is a useful tool to understand the systemic changes induced by any type of treatment. A video demonstrating the mouse preparation for blood pressure measurement is shown in Methods Video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2].
Software setup for the CODATM Non-invasive blood pressure system
Personnel Manager
Go to “Tools,” then select “Manage Personnel.”
In the “Researcher” tab, click on the “+” button and add the Researcher’s name or identifying information as preferred. Additional researchers can be added if needed.
Click the “save icon” to save the information.
Select the “Technicians Tab” to modify or add a new technician, following the same instructions used for adding a new researcher.
To select the specimens, go to “Specimens Tab” and click on the “+” button.
Add a name for the animal, and then select “Mouse” in the column “type.”
Click on the “save icon” to save the information, and then close the “Manage Personnel” window.
Create a new experiment (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A)
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Experiment Setup in CODA™ Software for Blood Pressure Measurement
(A) New Experiment window.
(B) Session Info window.
(C) Specimen Selection window.
(D) Session Parameters window.

(E) Final window showing “Finish” button that will begin the experiment.
        Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
      
Methods Video S2. Measurement of Maternal Blood Pressure (Refer to Blood Pressure Measurement, Step 12)
Select “File,” then “New,” then “Experiment.”
Enter the name of the experiment.
Select a Researcher.
Select a Begin Date and click “Next.”
Basic Session Info (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B)
Enter a Session name. We recommend using the same name that you are using to identify the mouse of interest. (e.g., DTR #1).
Enter the number of acclimation cycles. We recommend selecting 5 acclimation cycles.
Enter the number of sets. We recommend selecting 2 sets to improve the chance of successful measurement.
Set the time between sets to 30 s.
Enter the cycles per set. We recommend selecting 15 cycles per set.
Set the time between cycles to 5 s.
Click “Next” to go to the Specimen Selection.
Specimen Selection (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C)
Select the specimen by double-clicking on it, and move it into the “active specimens.” Be careful to add the specimen to the appropriate channel that you are going to use.
Click “Next” to go to the Session parameters.
Session Parameters (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D)
Select the Max Occlusion Pressure. We recommend selecting “250.”
Select the Deflation time. We recommend selecting “20.”
Select the Minimum Volume. We recommend selecting “15.”
Set the Display Style. We recommend selecting “One Channel Per Graph.”
If needed, add Additional Researchers or Technicians by double-clicking on them.
Click “Next” to go to the Session Script.
Check the Session Script to ensure that all the entered parameters are correct, and click “Next.”
Do not click “Finish” until the mouse is inside the restrainer and you are ready to perform the experiment (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E). Once you click “Finish,” the experiment will start.
Animal Setup
Animal restrainer

Place the cage containing the mouse next to the CODA™ platform.
Open the restrainer, removing the rear hatch. Release the nasal cone in order to have free movement in case the nasal cone needs to be moved while placing the mouse into the restrainer.
Hold the mouse by the base of its tail and place it into the restrainer with its head facing toward the nasal cone.
Secure the rear hatch, being careful not to pinch the mouse’s tail or any other body parts. Keep its tail in your hand the entire time, do not release it.
While holding the mouse by the base of its tail, slide the nasal cone backward to limit the mouse’s movements. Secure the nasal cone.
Place the restrainer over the warming platform. Keep the mouse on the warming platform for 5 min to acclimate it. We recommend covering the restrainer with a dark cloth to reduce stress to the mouse.
Cuff Setting (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A)
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Mouse Setup and Representative Data for Blood Pressure Measurement
(A) Mouse restrainer and cuff setup for blood pressure measurement.
(B) Representative curve indicating an accepted cycle.
(C) Representative report from a successful blood pressure measurement. Red square shows the average Diastolic, Systolic, and Mean measurements.
See also Methods Video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2].
Place the mouse’s tail into the “Occlusion cuff.” The cuff should be placed as close as possible to the base of the mouse’s tail, without forcing it.
Place the mouse’s tail into the “VPR Cuff.” The tail should be placed within 3 mm of the “Occlusion Cuff.”
Secure the tubing of both cuffs in the slot located at the top rear of the restrainer.
Experiment
Start the experiment.
To start the experiment, click “Finish” in the “Experiment Wizard” window. The experiment will start immediately.

Upon starting the experiment, a curve similar to that shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B should appear.
End the experiment
After ending the experiment, a new window will appear called “Simple session summary report.” This can be closed.
Once the experiment is finished, remove the cuffs from the tail and return the mouse to its cage.
Data Collection
After returning the mouse to its cage, click on the “Review an Experiment” icon.
Select the experiment that you just performed.
Click on the “Full Report” button.
Select all of the options and click “Ok.”
Advance to the summary of the “Accepted Cycles.”
Record the Mean value of the Diastolic, Systolic, and Mean pressures (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Close the software and turn off the machine.
Critical: Never leave the mouse unattended. If the cuffs are dislodged, re-adjust them to the correct position. If the mouse is not quiet and is moving its tail inside the restrainer, see Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]: Problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
High-Resolution Doppler Ultrasound Measurement
Timing: 45 min

High-resolution Doppler ultrasound has emerged as a key tool for evaluating maternal and fetal well-being. In the clinical setting, maternal Doppler ultrasound assessment (i.e., uterine arteries) is used to stratify the risk of developing pre-eclampsia and intra-uterine growth restriction (Martin et al., 2001[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]; Figueras and Gratacos, 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]; Poon et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16]; Sotiriadis et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib21]). Moreover, the umbilical artery Doppler is used to evaluate fetal well-being and to predict deleterious outcomes in a fetus with fetal growth restriction (Yoon et al., 1993[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib26]; Turan et al., 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib24]; Tarca et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib23]; Meyer et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]). In addition, the Doppler wave shape can be used to measure fetal heart rate. A video demonstrating the anesthesia and mouse preparation for ultrasound is shown in Methods Video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]. A video summarizing the high-resolution Doppler ultrasound procedure is shown in Methods Video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]. Representative videos of the maternal and fetal heartbeats are shown in Methods Videos S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5] and S6[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc6].
Setting Up the Vevo® Ultrasound software (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A)

imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Ultrasound Station and Experiment Setup
(A) Ultrasound station showing the primary components for ultrasound experiments.
(B) New Study window showing the experiment setup.
(C) Isoflurane vaporizer connected to the anesthesia induction chamber containing the mouse.
See also Methods Video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3].
New Study

Once the ultrasound is turned on, click on the “New” button located at the top of the screen.
Click on “New Study.”
Enter the Study name (e.g., “Star Protocol”) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Select the “Owner.”
Optional: Enter the “Grant Institution.”
Enter the “Series Name.” We recommend keeping the “Series name” the same as the “Animal ID.”
In “Acquired By,” select the person who is going to perform the ultrasound experiment.
In “Application,” select “General imaging.”
In “Measurement Package,” select “Cardiac Package.”
In “Animal ID,” copy and paste the name chosen as the “Series Name.”
Enter the “Color,” “Strain,” “Weight,” “Date of birth,” and “Sex” of the mouse.
Select “Pregnant” and add the “date plugged.”
In “Series note” experimental details or notes can be recorded.
Click on the “Ok” button located in the top-right corner of the screen.
If the 3D motor stage is connected, there will be a message asking whether you would like to initialize it. Select “No”.
Anesthesia (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C)
Turn on the oxygen tank and set the oxygen flow to 2 L/min.
Turn on the isoflurane and set it to 2%.
Remove the mouse from its cage and place it into the “Induction chamber.”
Start a timer immediately after placing the mouse in the “Induction chamber.”
After 3 min, remove the tubing from the “Induction chamber” and connect it to the tubing for the nasal mask on the heating pad at the ultrasound station.
Carefully remove the mouse from the “Induction chamber” and move it to the heating pad of the ultrasound station.
Place the mouse in the supine position (i.e., with the face and torso facing up) and connect the mouse’s snout to the nasal mask on the heating pad. If the mouse starts moving, see Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]: Problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].

Place 1 drop of Syntane® lubricant eye ointment on a cotton swab (approximately 3mm in diameter). Use the swab to place the drop in one of the mouse’s eyes, and then repeat this step for the other eye (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Mouse Preparation and Transducer Positioning Prior to Ultrasound Measurement
(A) Application of eye lubricant to mouse.
(B) Application of depilatory cream to mouse abdomen.
(C) Spreading of depilatory cream over mouse abdomen.
(D) Mouse abdomen after hair removal with taped paws and rectal probe inserted.
(E) Application of ultrasound gel on mouse abdomen.
(F) Transverse positioning of the transducer over the mouse abdomen prior to ultrasound measurement.
See also Methods Videos S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3] and S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4].
Fur Removal
Apply Nair™ depilatory cream to the mouse’s abdomen (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Spread the cream from the pubis to the ribs of the mouse using circular movements with a clean cotton swab (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C).
Continue massaging with circular movements for approximately 3 min.
Using the same cotton swab, remove as much fur as possible.
Take a piece of dampened gauze and start removing the fur and the cream. Use as many gauze pads as needed to remove all of the Nair™ cream.
In case there are still areas of fur that were not removed by the initial application of Nair™ cream, more Nair™ cream can be applied locally in these spots. All of the abdominal fur must be removed prior to performing the ultrasound (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]D).
Critical: Nair® cream can irritate the skin of the mouse, even causing chemical burns. Therefore, it is imperative to remove the cream completely with the dampened gauze. Avoid applying Nair® cream to the genital area of the mouse because irritation may occur and be a confounding variable for the experiment.

Fixation of the mouse and insertion of the rectal probe (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]D).
Remove the Aquasonic® ultrasound gel from the oven and place a drop of gel on each of the electrodes of the heating pad.
Take each of the mouse’s paws and secure them on the electrodes of the heating pad using the tape that was previously prepared.
Place a drop of the Aquagel® lubricating gel on a napkin and spread the gel on the tip of the rectal probe (thermometer) before inserting the rectal probe into the anus of the mouse.
Hold the tail and insert the rectal probe in the anus of the mouse.
Secure the rectal probe to the heating pad using the last piece of tape that was previously prepared.
General ultrasound scan (B-mode)
Take the Aquasonic® ultrasound gel out of the oven and shake it vigorously to move all of the gel toward the nozzle to avoid creating bubbles.
Cover the mouse’s abdomen with the Aquasonic® ultrasound gel (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]E). Avoid creating bubbles because they can distort the image.
The transducer should be oriented transverse to the abdomen and positioned directly over the lower part of the abdomen (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]F). If the ultrasound image is disturbed/not clear, see Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]: Problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Count and determine the localization of the pups (Figures 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A&B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Representative Maternal Bladder Imaging and Mapping of Pups
(A) Representative ultrasound image showing the maternal bladder from the transverse view.
(B) Example of drawn map showing the location of each pup relative to the maternal bladder.
See also Methods Video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4].

First, localize the maternal bladder. It is usually located in the midline and is recognized as a non-echogenic round structure. Its size will vary according to the presence of urine. This organ is going to be our reference point for localizing and mapping the pups (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
Once the bladder is identified, start scanning the abdominal midline of the mouse from the bladder to the sternum. We recommend drawing the position of the pups immediately after identifying them to document the correct number of pups as well as the correct location of each.
Once you finish scanning the midline, move the transducer back to the bladder (reference point). Then, using the bar located under the stage, tilt the heating pad to orient the right side of the mouse higher than the left side.
With the mouse tilted, start scanning from the bottom to the upper part of the right side, counting and localizing the pups on this side.
Repeat the previous two steps for the left side of the mouse.
Upon finishing the general scan, you should have a map similar to the one shown in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B showing the distribution of each pup.
Umbilical Artery Doppler Ultrasound
To obtain representative measurements and to avoid keeping the mouse under anesthesia for too long, we performed the measurements in three pups per dam. We included the first pup in each uterine horn plus one of the pups that is easier to measure according to its position.
After you localize the pup to measure, scan its abdominal wall as well as the placenta to identify the position of the umbilical cord.
Press the “Color” button to activate the color Doppler and to better identify the umbilical cord.

You can adjust the size of the square frame of the color Doppler to make it larger or smaller by pressing the “Update” button and simultaneously moving the scroll ball.
Adjust the “Velocity” button to optimize the vessel image.
Adjust the “Doppler Gain” button to optimize the vessel image.
The umbilical artery is the vessel that has a pulsatile image.
You can use the “Image depth” button as well as the “Zoom” button to better localize the umbilical cord. To obtain an optimal measurement, focus on the area of the umbilical cord between the placenta and the abdominal wall of the pup.
Press the “PW” button to activate the pulsed-wave Doppler.
Using the scroll ball, move the cursor to place it at the center of the umbilical cord. Adjust the size of the cursor by moving the “SV/Gate” up or down. The cursor has to be inside of the umbilical artery. If not, the measurement is going to include the umbilical vein, distorting the wave shape.
Adjust the angle of insonation by turning the “PW angle” button. The angle has to be as close to 0o as possible. An angle <30o is acceptable.
Press the “PW” button again to see the wave of the umbilical artery.
If the entire wave is not seen, the baseline can be moved down using the “baseline” button.
If the wave is inverted, its direction can be modified by pressing the “Invert” button.
Once an adequate wave shape is obtained, press the “Cine Store” button to save a mini-video of the measurement. The typical wave shape of the umbilical artery is shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/218-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Umbilical and Uterine Artery Measurement
(A) Representative image of the typical wave shape of the umbilical artery.

(B) Representative image of the typical wave shape of the uterine artery.
(C) Study Management window for selecting ultrasound videos to measure velocity and heart rate.
(D) User interface showing the icons for measuring velocity and heart rate.
(E) Representative measurement of the umbilical artery peak systolic velocity, end diastolic velocity, and fetal heart rate.
(F) Representative measurement of the uterine artery peak systolic velocity, end diastolic velocity, and maternal heart rate.
(G) Representative data output from maternal-fetal evaluation experiment. GA, Gestational Age; HR, Heart Rate; PSV, Peak Systolic Velocity; EDV, End Diastolic Velocity; PI, Pulsatility Index; RI, Resistance Index.
See also Methods Videos S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5] and S6[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc6].
Press the “Study Management” button to double check that the video was recorded and tag the video with the number of the pup. Do not perform the data analysis while the mouse is under anesthesia (This step will be performed later).
To tag the video, double click within the video frame.
Press the “Cine Loop Review” button.
Press the “Annotate” button.
Enter an ID for the pup (e.g., #1) and press “Enter.” To go back to the ultrasound scan screen, click the “Scan/Freeze” button.
Repeat the same procedure for each of the three pups.
Uterine artery Doppler ultrasound
Apply the Aquasonic® ultrasound gel to the lower part of the abdomen, mainly to the suprapubic area.
Rotate the ultrasound transducer 90o (oriented toward the sagittal axis of the mouse) and place it on the bladder.
To measure both uterine arteries (right and left), first localize the arteries by activating the “color” Doppler.
Move the transducer slowly from the middle line to the right side. The uterine artery is a curve-shaped artery that has a high velocity flow; therefore, the color that you will see varies between red, yellow, and blue (i.e., aliasing).

Once you localize the artery that seems to correspond to the uterine artery, press the “PW” button. The uterine artery is characterized by having a velocity of >100 cm/s. If the artery has a velocity <100 cm/s, it is likely not the uterine artery. Therefore, continue moving the transducer until the uterine artery is found.
Once an optimal wave is obtained, press the “Cine Store” button. The typical wave shape of the uterine artery is shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B.
Press the “Study management” button to double-check that the video was recorded and to identify the artery that was measured, following the same steps used for the identification of the umbilical artery.
Repeat the same procedure in the left uterine artery.
Completing the animal experiment
After obtaining the measurement of the left uterine artery, lift the transducer up.
Wipe off all of the Aquasonic® ultrasound gel from the mouse with the dampened gauze.
Remove the tape from the rectal probe (thermometer) and carefully remove the rectal probe from the rectum.
Remove the tape from the paws of the mouse and clean them off.
Depending on the aim of the study, you can leave the mouse in a recovery cage with a heating lamp. It should be recovered in about 5–10 min after removal from anesthesia. On the other hand, if the mouse will not be used to observe pregnancy or neonatal outcomes, it can be euthanized by cervical dislocation while still unconscious from anesthesia.
Turning off the anesthesia and oxygen and cleaning the machine
Immediately after removing the mouse from the nasal mask, stop the timer and record the length of the experiment.
Turn the Isoflurane to 0% and the oxygen to 0 L/min.
Turn off the oxygen tank.

While the oxygen tank is off, turn the oxygen to 10 L/min to flush the rest of the oxygen from the system.
Remove the isoflurane tubing from the nasal mask back and connect it back to the “induction chamber.”
Clean all of the gel from the heating pad as well as the ultrasound transducer.
Disinfect the thermometer, heating pad, and probe with disinfectant spray.
Analysis of umbilical artery and fetal heart rate
Go to “Study management” (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C).
Select the video of the first umbilical artery measured by double-clicking on it (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C).
The video will start playing immediately. Stop the video in the desired section by pressing the “Cine Loop Review” button. You can alter the loop by adjusting the same “Cine Loop Review” button.
Press the “Measure” button.
To measure the peak systolic velocity, click on the “Velocity” button (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]D).
Place the cursor on the wave crest and left click (select). This number corresponds to the peak systolic velocity of the umbilical artery (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]E).
Click on the “Velocity” button again to measure the end diastolic velocity. Place the cursor on the wave trough. This number corresponds to the end diastolic velocity of the umbilical artery (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]E).
To measure the fetal heart, click on the “Heart Rate” button. Place the cursor at the beginning of one of the waves and left click (select) (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]D).
Move the cursor to the beginning of the next wave and right click “Update.” This number corresponds to the fetal heart rate (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]E).
Repeat the same procedure for each of the three pups measured.
Record all of the data for further analysis.
Analysis of the uterine artery and maternal heart rate
Go to “Study management.”
Select the video of the right uterine artery by double-clicking on it.
Repeat the same procedures used to analyze the umbilical artery (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]F).
